answers.answer: Yes.It will cause medications to not work. That should be a hint or a giant clue to doctors that something else is going on, but eh, it usually means the doctor will think the patient is non-compliant or some other reason.I have seen specifically in the case of Cushing's disease, anti-depressants, diabetes, acne and blood pressure medications not work. Other tumors may be the same, I just don't have the experience talking to the patients a great deal.It has not been studied as far as I know or can find - but heck, the meds work with the body and in this case, the body is working way against you.Taking excessive amounts will not work - it will only be toxic. The only way is to determine the source of the issue and to eradicate it.

question: Can a pituitary adenoma cause changes in how medications work?  If it can or can't, can someone please explain?  I have been on every medication around (not for thyroid or pituitary, etc...) and they all seem to either not work or only work if I take a very excessive amount.  Thanks!
title: Can a pituitary adenoma cause changes in how medications work?
